Having attained a fortunate rebirth,
May my spiritual commitments remain unbroken even there.

May scholars be honored and respected, and may they easily obtain the alms they need. May their minds be completely purified, and may their good reputation spread throughout all directions.

 Expanded Translation

May the learned ones be respected and honored, and may they receive ample provisions through alms-giving. May their mental streams be thoroughly purified, and may their noble reputation spread in all directions throughout the world.
May they never experience the sufferings of the lower realms, and without needing to undergo difficult austerities, may they swiftly attain Buddhahood with a body more sublime than even the gods.
May all sentient beings make abundant offerings to all the Buddhas, and may they forever dwell in happiness through the inconceivable bliss of Buddhahood.
May the aspirations of the bodhisattvas for the welfare of all beings be completely fulfilled. May all sentient beings receive exactly what these protectors have envisioned for them.
Likewise, may all Pratyekabuddhas and Śrāvakas experience happiness.
Through the kindness of Mañjuśrī, until I attain the Ground of Perfect Joy, may I always remember my past lives and obtain the renunciant's life in every rebirth.
May I sustain myself with simple food while maintaining my vitality and strength. Throughout all my future lifetimes, may I obtain perfect conditions for dwelling in solitude.

Whenever I wish to see the divine face of Mañjuśrī or desire to ask even the smallest question, may I behold that very protector, Mañjuśrī himself, without any obstacles or hindrances.

In other words: May I, without any impediment, directly perceive Lord Mañjuśrī whenever I wish to gaze upon him or whenever I seek answers, even to minor inquiries. May this wisdom deity be immediately accessible to me, revealing himself clearly and directly as my spiritual protector and guide on the path of wisdom.

For the benefit of all sentient beings throughout the ten directions, extending to the very limits of space, I aspire to conduct myself exactly as Mañjuśrī does. Just as he works tirelessly to fulfill the welfare of all beings, may my own actions likewise be dedicated entirely to accomplishing the well-being of all sentient creatures.
For as long as space itself endures, and for as long as living beings remain in this world, may I too continue to exist, dedicated to dispelling the sufferings of all beings.
Whatever suffering exists in the world, may all of it ripen upon me. Through the virtuous actions of all bodhisattvas, may all beings experience happiness.

The unique medicine for all beings' suffering,
The source from which all happiness arises,
May the teachings, along with material support and reverence,
Remain in this world for a very long time.
I bow to Mañjughoṣa, by whose kindness virtuous thought arises in me. I also pay homage to my spiritual guides, through whose kindness I have grown and flourished.

This concludes the tenth chapter entitled 'Dedication of Merit' from the Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life.

Here ends the Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life, composed by Master Śāntideva.

This text was first translated from a Kashmiri manuscript by the Indian preceptor Sarvajñadeva and the great translator Bande Paltsegs, who established a definitive Tibetan version. Later, this translation was revised by the Indian preceptor Dharmaśrībhadra working together with the great translators Bande Rinchen Zangpo and Śākya Lodrö. They compared it with a manuscript from Central India and its commentary, made corrections, and established an improved version.

Subsequently, at a later time, the Indian preceptor Sumatikīrti and the great translator monk Loden Sherab thoroughly corrected and retranslated the text, establishing an excellent definitive version.

books.title: The Way of the Bodhisattva AI Draft, Feb 2025
content:
༄༅༅། །
In the language of India [Sanskrit]: Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra [The Way of the Bodhisattva]
In Tibetan: A Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life
Homage to all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

With reverence I prostrate with body, speech and mind to all the perfectly-gone, never-returning Sugatas possessing the twofold dharmakāya,
Together with their noble heirs born from wisdom and compassion, and all who are worthy of veneration.
The entrance into the threefold discipline of these children of the Sugatas—restraint, virtue-gathering, and benefiting beings—
I shall now concisely explain according to authentic scripture, suitable for beings of these degenerate times.

I have nothing new to say here that has not been said before.
Nor do I possess any skill in composition.
Therefore, I have not written this with the intention to benefit others.
I have composed this solely to cultivate my own mind.

For cultivating virtue, my force of faith
Shall, for the time being, increase through these verses.
And should others of equal spiritual fortune
Chance upon these teachings, they too will find their path fulfilled.

This precious human life with its eight freedoms and ten endowments,
So rare to find—like a blind turtle meeting a floating yoke—enables the highest Dharma purpose.
If, having obtained this fleeting treasure through past virtue, you fail to practice the holy Dharma,
How could such perfect conditions ever be gathered again as death approaches uncertainty?

Just as in the night's darkness midst dense clouds
Lightning momentarily illuminates with brilliant light
So too by Buddha's power, once in a hundred times
Wisdom and merit briefly arise in worldly beings' minds

Therefore virtue remains perpetually feeble,
While sin's power is mighty and utterly unbearable.
What virtue other than the mind of perfect enlightenment  
Could possibly overcome such terrible forces?

Having thoroughly contemplated over countless eons,
The Lords of Sages perceived that this alone brings benefit;
Through this, countless multitudes of beings
Effortlessly attain supreme bliss.

Those who wish to overcome hundreds of sufferings of existence,
Who desire to dispel the unhappiness of sentient beings,
Who wish to experience hundreds of happinesses, both temporary and ultimate—
Should never, ever abandon bodhicitta, the awakening mind.

The moment bodhicitta awakens in one's mind,
The wretched one, once bound in saṃsāra's prison,
Is instantly proclaimed a child of the Sugatas,
And becomes worthy of prostrations from gods and humans throughout the world.

Like the supreme alchemical elixir that transforms into gold,
Taking this impure body and transmuting it into the priceless, jewel-like form of the Victorious One,
Therefore, firmly grasp without wavering
This supreme mind of awakening called bodhicitta.

The world's sole captains, with wisdom immeasurable and all-pervading,
Having thoroughly examined all phenomena through countless eons, found most precious,
Those who wish to be freed from samsara's realms of wandering,
Firmly grasp this supreme jewel—the jewel of bodhicitta.

All other virtuous deeds, like a plantain tree,
Will ultimately be exhausted after bearing fruit.
Yet the wish-fulfilling tree of bodhicitta
Bears fruit without depletion, ever growing in abundance.

Even if one has committed most terrible negative acts,
Just as one escapes grave dangers by relying on a hero,
Which instantly liberates one when relied upon,
Why would those conscientious about proper conduct not depend on it?

Like the fire at the end of time that consumes all worlds, bodhicitta
Instantly burns away even the five heinous crimes.
These immeasurable benefits
The wise protector Maitreya explained to Sudhana, noble merchant's son.

That bodhicitta, in brief,
Should be understood as having two aspects:
The aspirational mind toward enlightenment,
And the engagement in enlightenment itself.

Just as one discerns the difference between
Wishing to go and actually going somewhere,
So should the wise understand
These two types in sequence.

Though the aspiring mind of awakening (bodhipraṇidhicitta) yields
Great fruits while wandering in saṃsāra,
It does not generate continuous merit
As does the engaging mind (prasthānacitta).

From the moment one firmly takes up that engagement bodhichitta
For the sake of liberating the boundless realm of sentient beings,
With an irreversible mind that will not turn back—
A merit vast as space flows ceaselessly, even in sleep and inattention,

From the moment one formally takes the engaged bodhicitta vow
Powerful streams of merit, vast as space itself
Flow forth unceasingly in boundless measure
Even during sleep or times of heedlessness

This teaching on engaged bodhicitta,
Was expounded by the Tathāgata himself,
For the sake of beings of inferior motivation,
Those śrāvakas who turned away from the Mahāyāna path.

When one merely thinks of the headaches of beings,
'I shall dispel them'—even just this thought,
This compassionate intent to benefit others,
Endows one with immeasurable merit.

Wishing to remove
The immeasurable sufferings of each and every being,
And aspiring to establish each one in boundless qualities
Of enlightenment—what need is there to speak of such merit?

What mother or father could possess such altruistic intention?
Who has such wish for others to attain Buddhahood?
Not even among gods and truth-speaking sages,
Nor even in Brahma himself, does this profound concern exist.

For these very beings
Even for their own sake, this wish
Not even in dreams has such a thought ever appeared
How then could it possibly arise for the benefit of others?

Others do not generate even for their own sake
The mind that contemplates the welfare of sentient beings
This special jewel of mind bodhicitta
Has arisen—an unprecedented marvel

The cause of joy for all wandering beings,
The elixir for the suffering of all sentient beings,
This precious mind whose merit is boundless,
How could one possibly measure such merit?

Even through the mere intention to benefit others,
One surpasses the merit of making offerings to Buddhas.
What need is there to mention striving 
For the happiness of all sentient beings without exception?

Though beings wish to be free from suffering,
They rush toward suffering itself like moths to flames.
Though longing for happiness through present and future lives,
Through delusion about what to adopt and reject,
They destroy their own happiness as if it were an enemy.

To those who are deprived of joy,
And burdened with manifold sufferings,
May I bring fulfillment through happiness,
And sever completely all suffering.

It even dispels ignorance.
Where is virtue equal to this?
Where is such a beneficial friend?
Where is merit like this?

One who repays kindness received is, for now, deemed praiseworthy,
What need, then, to mention the bodhisattva who,
Without being asked, performs virtuous deeds,
What need, then, to mention the bodhisattva?

One who provides ordinary meals to merely a few people,
Is honored as virtuous by the world, though their gift is slight,
Whether giving food for just a moment's sustenance,
Or providing half a day's nourishment with disdain.

That bestows upon limitless beings throughout endless time
The unsurpassed bliss of the Tathāgatas,
Completely fulfilling all wishes in every mind until space and beings are no more?
What need is there to mention the inexhaustible generosity

Whoever harbors malice in their heart
Toward a Bodhisattva, the Victor's heir who serves as patron,
Will dwell in the hell realms for as many kalpas
As moments of ill will generated—thus the Sage declared.

However, if one generates a mind of pure devotion,
The fruits thereof will multiply far more abundantly.
For the children of the Conqueror, even under great duress,
No negativity arises, while virtuous qualities naturally increase.

I prostrate to the bodies of those
In whom that precious jewel of supreme bodhicitta has arisen
I go for refuge to those sources of happiness
Who transform even harmful acts into connections with happiness.
Thus concludes the first chapter from the 'Introduction to the Conduct of Bodhisattvas' (Bodhicaryāvatāra), entitled 'Explanation of the Benefits of Bodhicitta.'

To generate and hold this precious bodhicitta mind,
I make perfect offerings to the Tathāgatas and the sublime Dharma,
To the immaculate jewel free from all conceptual elaborations,
And to the Buddha's children, the Bodhisattvas—these oceans of qualities.

Whatever flowers and fruits there are in existence,
And whatever varieties of medicines there are in existence,
And whatever precious substances exist in the world,
And whatever pure, delightful waters there are in existence.

mountains of precious jewels like Meru and golden peaks
forest realms secluded peaceful as turquoise mandalas
trees resplendent adorned with blossoming flower ornaments
and those whose branches bow low bearing excellent fruits

In the realms of gods and celestial beings, there are divine fragrances and incense,
Wish-fulfilling trees and trees made of precious gems,
Crops that grow without being cultivated,
And other ornaments worthy of offering.

Oceans and lakes adorned with lotuses,
Swans with beautiful and pleasing songs,
Throughout the vast expanse of space to its limits,
All these that cannot be possessed.

Having gathered with my mind the supreme sage, the best of humans,
I present these well to him and his heirs.
May these holy recipients with immense compassion,
Accept my offerings with kindness, considering me with love.

Having surrendered myself completely into your care,
I remain fearless in saṃsāra while working for beings' welfare.
I shall transcend my previous negative deeds,
And henceforth commit no further wrongdoing.

In those exceedingly fragrant bathing chambers
With floors of crystal that are clear and brilliantly gleaming
Adorned with captivating pillars of radiant jewels
Covered with canopies that shimmer with the luminous glow of pearls

To the Tathāgatas and their spiritual children,
I offer ablution with numerous gemstone vessels
Filled with fragrant, mind-pleasing waters,
Accompanied by melodious songs and musical instruments.

With incomparable garments of divine cloth and Kāśika silk,
I cleanse their sacred bodies with perfumed, immaculate cloths,
Then I offer them excellent robes well-dyed in the three allowable colors,
Presenting supremely fragrant, exquisite vestments.

With divine garments—soft, smooth, and splendidly varied in form,
And the finest ornaments of countless kinds adorning them,
I honor noble Samantabhadra, wise Manjushri,
And Lokeshvara, Lord of the World, along with other exalted bodhisattvas.

With supreme fragrances whose sweet scents pervade the entire trichiliocosm,
I anoint the bodies of all the Lords of Sages with these finest scents.
Like pure gold well-melted, thoroughly refined, and perfectly polished,
Their radiant forms brilliantly blaze with captivating light.

I worship the supreme Lords of Sages, most worthy of reverence,
With mandārava, lotus, and all fragrant flowers delightful to the mind;
With utpala and all other fragrant items,
And beautifully arranged garlands that are pleasing to the mind.

I offer billowing clouds of fragrant incense with rich aromas spreading, delightfully captivating the mind.
I present various delectable foods, edible delights, and drinks—divine offerings worthy of the exalted ones.
With rich aromas spreading, delightfully captivating the mind.
Divine offerings worthy of the exalted ones I reverently serve.

I mentally offer jeweled lamps upon rows of gleaming golden lotuses of Jambu,
Placed on golden lotus arrangements, their radiant light dispelling the darkness of ignorance.
On gem-inlaid floors anointed with fragrant substances the thickness of a cow's hide,
I scatter pleasing stemless flower petals, spread knee-high across this sacred ground.

I offer these celestial mansions adorned with pearl and jewel necklaces
Resplendent ornaments of the quarters where enchanting hymns of praise resound
These clouds of divine palaces illuminating the boundless sky with their beauty
To those whose nature is compassion that all beings may reach liberation's realm

I offer these magnificent jeweled parasols with golden handles,
Adorned with precious gems and auspicious patterns in splendid array,
Beautifully shaped and raised aloft, delightful to behold,
These I continuously present to the mighty sages.

Furthermore, may magnificent clouds of offerings stand forth,
With instruments played, struck, and blown with their eight sublime qualities,
May clouds of music and melody that delight the mind and soothe,
Relieving all beings' suffering, pervade before the Victorious Ones and their heirs.

Upon all precious Dharma jewels, both scriptural and realized,
Upon stupas of Buddha's eight activities and images painted, cast, and sculpted,
May showers of jewels, flowers, and manifold offerings
Fall incessantly without interruption until samsara ends.

Just as Mañjuśrī, Samantabhadra and others
Make magnificent offerings to the Victorious Ones,
So shall I make offerings to the Tathāgata protectors
Together with their spiritual heirs.

I praise the oceans of qualities—the Buddha Blessed Ones with their physical marks, Brahma-voice, and omniscient wisdom—and their bodhisattva heirs
With oceans of melodious expressions of praise, where melody is speech, limbs are its causes, and ocean signifies their multiplicity.
May these sweet clouds of eulogizing melodies
Definitely arise before them perpetually in all times and places, even without my continuous offering.

To all Buddhas throughout the three times,
Together with the sublime Dharma and supreme Assembly,  
With bodies as numerous as atoms in all buddha-fields,
I reverently bow down and prostrate myself.

I bow to all stūpas and the foundations of the awakening mind.
I pay homage to the preceptors,
I likewise venerate the teachers,
Those of supreme disciplined conduct.

Until I reach the essence of enlightenment,
I go for refuge to the Buddhas. 
To the Dharma and the assembly of Bodhisattvas,
Likewise, I go for refuge.

To those dwelling in all directions,
The perfectly awakened Buddhas and the bodhisattvas,
All who possess great compassion,
With joined palms, I make this supplication.

From beginningless saṃsāra,
In this life or in other births,
I have committed naturally wrongful deeds,
Or directed others to do the same.

Overwhelmed by ignorance and confusion,
Whatever actions I've rejoiced in,
Having recognized these wrongdoings,
I confess to the Protector with all my heart.

Whatever harm I have inflicted on the Three Jewels,
And on my parents or spiritual teachers or others,
Through the afflictions, by means of my body, speech,
And mind—all this I hereby confess.

I, defiled by numerous faults like attachment clinging like rust,
A sinner who has committed utterly unbearable harmful deeds,
All these terrible sins that I have done, which may bring death at any moment,
With genuine remorse I confess before all guides—the Buddhas and their heirs.

With my negative actions still unpurified,
I will be taken by the Lord of Death prematurely.
How can I be definitively liberated from these misdeeds?
I implore you, protect me swiftly, that I may take refuge!

The Lord of Death, utterly beyond trust,
Waits not for deeds done or yet unbegun.
Whether healthy or sick, life is but a breath—
Never trust this fleeting life will endure.

Not knowing I must abandon everything and depart utterly alone,
I committed numerous sins through attachment and aversion,
For the sake of those dear to me and against those not dear,
All meaningless actions that bring only suffering when I depart.

Just as with experiences in a dream,
Whatever objects one experiences
Become merely objects of memory,
All that has passed will not be seen again.

Even in this very life, while you yet remain,
Many beloved and non-beloved ones have passed away;
Yet the unbearable evil deeds committed through attachment and aversion
Stand before you.

Thus I have not realized
I am but a sudden, temporary visitor in this world.
Through delusion, attachment, and hatred
I have committed many types of sins.

Day and night without respite,
Life constantly diminishes with no way to replenish,
No additional time comes from elsewhere,
How can I not meet death, I will surely die.

Though I lie here on my deathbed
Surrounded by all my relatives and friends
The unbearable pain of life being severed
I alone must endure.

When seized by the messengers of the Lord of Death,
What help can relatives provide? What benefit are friends?
At that critical moment, only merit serves as a refuge,
Yet even that I have not cultivated.

O Protector, through my heedlessness,
Not knowing these terrifying fears,
For the sake of this impermanent life,
I have committed many evil deeds.

Led today to where his limbs will be severed as punishment
The condemned man withers, gripped by terror profound
Parched with thirst, his gaze downcast and pitiful
He himself appears utterly transformed from before.

What more can be said of one seized by Yama's messengers
With terrifying forms—manifestations of one's own karma—
Afflicted by the great disease of terror,
Overwhelmed with dread while facing death's final torments?

Who will properly protect me from
This great terror? thinking thus,
With terrified eyes agape,
I frantically search in all four directions for refuge.

Seeing no refuge in the four directions,
I fall utterly into overwhelming despair.
In that terrifying place where no protection exists,
What shall I do then?

Thus to the Victor, the protector of beings,
Who strive for the purpose of defending all beings,
The powerful one who dispels all fears,
From this very day I go for refuge.

I take genuine refuge in the Dharma realized by the Buddhas
Which dispels all saṃsāra's fears;
And likewise in the noble assembly of bodhisattvas,
I sincerely take refuge without doubt.

Overwhelmed with terror from fears,
I offer myself to Samantabhadra.
To Mañjuśrī as well,
I surrender this body.

With compassionate activity that is unerring,
To that Lord Avalokiteśvara,
I cry out with a pitiful wail,
May he protect me, a sinner.

To noble Ākāśagarbha, Buddha-appointed staff-like support for fallen bodhisattvas,
To Kṣitigarbha, protector of the destitute overcome by afflictions though wearing monastic robes,
And to all great compassionate protectors like Maitreya and Viṣkambhin, lords of the ten grounds,
I, observing some precepts while breaking others, cry out in anguish from the depths of my heart seeking refuge.

Upon merely glimpsing Vajrapāṇi,
The messengers of Yama and all malevolent forces
Flee terrified in all four directions
I take refuge in this supreme Vajra-holder.

Having transgressed your sacred commands in the past,
Now seeing the great terrors,
I come to you for refuge;
Swiftly dispel these fears.

Even one frightened by a minor ailment,
Should not disregard the physician's words;
How much more when afflicted by hundreds of diseases,
From the four afflictions and their four derivatives?

When even one affliction like attachment or anger
Destroys all people dwelling in Jambudvīpa
What medicine that heals these mental poisons
Can be found in any direction, even in Brahma's realm

The Omniscient Physician
Who extracts all thorns of suffering
One who contemplates not following His instructions
Is utterly deluded, a proper object of reproach

If I must remain mindfully vigilant
Even at ordinary small precipices,
What need to mention the abyss of lower realms 
Where one falls a thousand yojanas for endless time?

Thinking 'I shall not die today,'
It is inappropriate to rest in comfort.
The time when I shall cease to exist
Will certainly come without fail.

Who has given me fearlessness?
How could I escape this fate?
Since I will inevitably perish,
Why does my mind remain at ease?

From all those pleasures I've experienced,
What lasting essence remains for me?
Yet fixated on such objects,
I've transgressed my guru's instructions.

Abandoning this present life with all its trappings
Leaving behind my relatives and friends alike
When I must journey alone driven helplessly by karma
What use are all these loved ones and enemies to me

From unwholesome actions suffering arises.
'How might I definitely escape from this?'
Day and night, constantly, I
Should think of this alone, as is proper.

Due to my ignorance and fundamental confusion,
Whether natural misdeeds wrong for all beings by nature,
Or prescribed wrongs forbidden only to those under vows,
Whatever such negative actions I have committed.

Standing directly before the Buddha protectors' omniscient gaze,
With joined palms, body trembling, fearful of lower realms' suffering,
I prostrate again and again, with profound remorse in every bow,
And confess all these misdeeds completely, turning away from each fault.

May the guides—Buddhas and Bodhisattvas—acknowledge
my transgressions as true faults.
O Protectors, these actions are not virtuous;
Henceforth I shall never again commit such deeds.
Thus concludes the second chapter entitled 'Confession of Negativities' (Pāpadeśanā) from the Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life (Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra).

I joyfully rejoice in all virtuous deeds performed by sentient beings
That provide relief from the sufferings of lower realms in cyclic existence.
May those afflicted with suffering abide in happiness.
Though still bound by samsara's nature, I celebrate their merit with genuine delight.

I rejoice in the virtues accumulated 
As causes for the enlightenment of renunciants
I rejoice in the definite liberation
Of embodied beings from the sufferings of saṃsāra

I rejoice in the enlightenment of the Buddhas, the protectors,
And in the progressive grounds attained by the Bodhisattvas.
In the mind that brings happiness to all sentient beings,
And the ocean of virtues arising from the generation of bodhicitta,
And in all actions performed for beings' benefit,
I rejoice.

With palms joined in reverence and offering, I supplicate
All the Buddhas throughout every direction:
For beings who fall into suffering due to ignorance's darkness,
Please kindle the lamp of Dharma teachings.

When the Conquerors wish to pass into nirvana,
With palms joined I offer this prayer:
May you not leave this world in blindness,
I beseech you to remain for countless eons.

Having thus performed all these practices,
Through whatever virtue I have accumulated,
May all sentient beings'
Sufferings be completely dispelled.

For as long as sentient beings are afflicted by illness,
Until they completely recover from their suffering,
May I become healing medicine and skilled physician,
And serve as their devoted attendant.

By showering down exquisite food and drink with their hundred flavors,
I shall completely dispel the suffering of hunger and thirst.
During the intermediate kalpa of famine with its phases of scarcity,
May I myself become nourishment for all beings—an offering worthy of merit.

For sentient beings impoverished and destitute,
May I become an inexhaustible treasure for them.
Manifesting as various necessities of every kind,
May I remain directly present before them.

The body, likewise enjoyments,
And all virtues of the three times,
For the sake of accomplishing the welfare of all sentient beings,
Should be given away without miserliness.

Through complete renunciation, nirvana is attained
My mind strives to accomplish this liberation
When everything must be relinquished simultaneously
Supreme is offering it to beings

Since I have already given this body
To all sentient beings as they please,
Let them at all times kill me, criticize me,
Or beat me—I accept whatever they choose.

Let them play with my body
Let them laugh, mock, and make it an object of ridicule
I have already given this body to all sentient beings
Why should I concern myself with protecting it?

Let them engage in actions 
That bring them well-being without causing harm
By the power of my dedication, may no being who focuses on me
Ever experience anything without purpose or benefit

When sentient beings take me as their object of mind,
Whether with anger arising or devoted faith,
May that very mental state forever become
The cause fulfilling all their worldly and ultimate aims.

Those who verbally criticize me
Those who inflict harm
Likewise those who mock
May all have the fortune of awakening.

I am the protector for those without protection,
and the guide for travelers on the path.
For those wishing to cross over, I serve as a boat,
and I become both a ship and a bridge for them.

For those who seek an island of refuge from life's turbulent waters, may I become an island
For those who desire a lamp in darkness to discern the righteous path, may I become a lamp
For those who need a dwelling place, may I become their shelter and resting place
I, for all embodied beings who require a servant
May I become a servant to all, fulfilling whatever they need

The wish-fulfilling jewel and excellent vase
The accomplished knowledge mantra and great medicine
The wish-fulfilling tree
May I become for all embodied beings

Like the great elements earth, water, fire, wind
And space that constantly pervades all,
May I become the foundation for immeasurable beings
The basis for their diverse needs and sustenance.

Thus, to the vast realm of beings that extends
Throughout all ways to space's farthest reach,
Until all have attained perfect nirvana,
May I become their sustaining source indeed.

Just as the ancient Sugatas,
Generated the awakening mind,
And trained in the bodhisattva's disciplines,
So I shall also follow in proper sequence.

Just as the Buddhas before me, for the welfare of the world, I too shall generate this awakening mind of bodhicitta.
Likewise, I shall progressively train in all the disciplines
According to their proper sequence.

Thus the wise bodhisattva
Having firmly grasped the awakening mind
To systematically prevent its decline
Should uplift the mind with joy.

Today my life has become fruitful
I have excellently obtained this human existence
Today I have been born into the Buddha's family
And I have now become a child of the Buddha

Now I must act in accordance with my lineage's ways,
Practicing diligently as Buddha's heirs have done,
So this flawless, noble lineage throughout all time
May never be stained or sullied by my misconduct.

Just as a blind person might find a precious jewel
Among heaps of discarded refuse,
So too, by mere chance and through the Buddha's blessing,
This bodhicitta has arisen in me.

This bodhicitta is the supreme nectar
That conquers the lord of death for all beings, bestowing deathlessness.
This awakening mind is indeed the inexhaustible treasure
That completely dispels both material and spiritual poverty for beings.

This is the supreme medicine of enlightened mind
That pacifies all diseases of sentient beings.
For those exhausted from wandering the long pathways of saṃsāra,
This is the sheltering tree where all weary beings find true rest.

A common platform for all beings.
It liberates them from the lower realms.
The moon of mind has risen
To dispel the torment of afflictions.

The great sun that thoroughly uproots
the cataracts of ignorance in the world,

The butter essence that emerges
from churning the milk of the sublime Dharma.

For wandering guests upon existence's path
Who yearn to taste the pleasures of delight,
This stands as supreme bliss, unfailing,
Satisfying all beings as great guests.

Today, before all Protectors,
I have invited all sentient beings to the Sugata state of enlightenment
And, meanwhile, to be guests to happiness along the path.
May gods, asuras, and all others rejoice in this invitation!
Thus concludes the third chapter entitled 'Thoroughly Adopting the Bodhicitta' (Bodhicittaparigraha) from 'Engaging in the Bodhisattva's Conduct' (Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra).

Thus, having firmly grasped bodhicitta with unwavering resolve,
The Child of the Victorious Ones who has taken the sacred vows
Must constantly remain vigilant without the slightest negligence,
And strive diligently never to transgress the bodhisattva trainings.

Whatever is rashly begun
Or that which has been insufficiently investigated,
Even though one has firmly committed oneself to such action,
It is proper to thoroughly analyze whether to accept or reject it.

That which the Buddhas and their spiritual heirs
Have thoroughly examined with their great wisdom,
And which I too have carefully analyzed through reasoning,
What excuse could there be to postpone its practice?

If, after making this solemn vow,
I fail to fulfill it through practical actions,
Having deceived all these sentient beings,
What shall become of my destiny?

Even for the most trivial of objects,
When one mentally resolves 'I shall give this,'
Yet fails to fulfill that intention,
It is taught that such a person becomes a hungry ghost.

Having sincerely aspired to supreme unsurpassed bliss
And invited all beings as honored guests through bodhicitta intention
If I then deceive all wandering beings
How could I possibly journey to higher realms?

How even those who abandon bodhicitta
Are still delivered to liberation.
This inconceivable workings of karma:
Only the Omniscient One truly knows.

For a bodhisattva, this transgression stands as the gravest downfall above all others.
When one abandons the awakened resolve.
The foundation for benefiting all beings is destroyed.
This diminishes one's ability to help all sentient beings.

Whoever, even for a moment, obstructs
The meritorious actions of this bodhisattva, 
Will face limitless suffering in lower realms,
Having impeded one who works for beings' welfare.

If destroying even one being's happiness
Causes one to fall from higher to lower realms,
Then what need to mention the karmic consequences
Of destroying the well-being of countless embodied beings throughout limitless space?

Thus, by the power of transgressing through abandonment of bodhicitta
And subsequently by the power of regenerating this awakening mind,
One oscillates in saṃsāra, swinging between realms due to these actions,
And long delays attainment of the bodhisattva bhūmis.

Therefore, as I have solemnly vowed,
I must respectfully fulfill my bodhisattva training.
If from today I fail to make diligent effort,
I will descend to lower realms.

Innumerable Buddhas have come and gone
Who diligently sought the welfare of all sentient beings
Yet due to my own faults alone, I have not become
A suitable recipient of their healing ministrations.

If I continue to act in this same manner still,
I shall experience again and again exactly thus:
Lower rebirths, disease, bondage in iron chains,
Cutting by swords, dismemberment by axes, and such sufferings.

The advent of a Tathāgata in this world,
Faith in the Buddha's Tripitaka teachings, this precious human form with its eighteen freedoms and advantages,
And circumstances suitable for practicing virtue,
When will I ever again obtain these rare conditions?

Though we enjoy this day free from illness.
With food to eat and no harm befalling us.
Life is momentary and deceptive.
This body, like something borrowed briefly.

With such conduct as mine,
I will not again obtain a precious human body.
Without attaining a human form,
Only negative actions will prevail, with no opportunity for virtue.

When, though endowed with leisure and fortune for virtuous action,
I fail to perform good deeds,
What shall I do when, in the lower realms' torment,
Completely deluded?

For one who neither performs virtuous deeds
And instead accumulates evil actions,
Even after hundreds of millions of eons,
The very word 'fortunate rebirth' will not be heard.

For this very reason the Blessed One declared
Human birth is exceedingly difficult to obtain
Even rarer than a blind turtle surfacing once every hundred years
Whose neck might chance upon a yoke's hole in the vast ocean

From a single moment's sin,
One dwells in Avīci hell for an entire eon.
With sins accumulated since beginningless saṃsāra,
What need is there to mention the uncertainty of reaching higher realms?

Merely by experiencing that suffering alone,
One will not attain liberation from the lower realms.
For while undergoing the ripening of previous deeds,
New evils arise—anger and malice perpetuating the cycle.

Having obtained this precious human rebirth,
If I have not cultivated virtue,
There exists no greater deception than this,
Nor greater delusion than this ignorance.

If, having realized this precious opportunity,
I later falter through delusion,
When the time of death arrives,
I shall be overcome with great sorrow.

The unbearable fires of hell will burn
My body for a long, long time to come.
Then the flames of remorse, equally torturous,
Will surely consume my mind that abandoned bodhicitta vows.

Having by rare coincidence obtained this extremely difficult-to-find human body—a precious foundation for spiritual benefit—
Though I possess the wisdom to distinguish virtue from non-virtue,
If I lead myself back to those same hell realms from which I once came,
It is as though I've been bewitched, forsaking my connection to the Buddha.

Like one bewildered by mantras,
I am here bereft of mental discernment.
I do not know by what affliction I am deluded;
What dwells within me causing this loss of control?

Enemies of hatred, craving, and the rest,
Have no limbs, legs, and so forth,
Not brave nor wise, yet somehow
They have made me their servant.

While dwelling within my mind as unwelcome intruders,
These enemy afflictions joyfully inflict their harm on me;
To show patience toward such destroyers without anger
Is misplaced tolerance, condemned by the Buddhas and noble ones.

Even if all the gods and demigods
Were to rise against me as enemies,
Even they would not be capable
Of dragging me into the fires of Avīci hell.

When these powerful enemies—my afflictions—arise,
Even Mount Meru would leave not a trace of ash when consumed by them;
I am cast in a single instant by these mighty foes of afflictions,
Into that terrible Avīci hell.

My affliction-enemies endure
Without beginning or end through boundless time;
Unlike them, no other adversaries,
However powerful, can last so long.

When served with respect and provided what they need,
Even ordinary enemies bring benefit and happiness.
But when inner afflictions are indulged,
They only cause repeated suffering and harm.

Thus, when these continuous and ancient foes—afflictions that have been enemies since beginningless time without a moment's interruption, the sole source producing all streams of suffering—fearlessly dwell in my heart, how could I possibly find joy in saṃsāra?

These afflictions, guardians of saṃsāra's three realms' prison,
Act as executioners in the Reviving Hell and lower states.
If they dwell in my mind, trapped in improper thought's attachment net,
How could I find any physical or mental well-being?

Therefore, until I have decisively conquered these enemies—the afflictions—
In direct perception, I shall not abandon my diligence in this practice.
Just as those inflated with pride and filled with anger at even slight offenses
Will not sleep until they have defeated their adversary.

Those afflictions—our enemies since birth, pitiable in their suffering from impermanence and death
When confronting them in battle, we must firmly resolve to destroy them
Enduring the pain of countless arrows, spears, and weapon strikes
We never turn back until we accomplish our goal, no matter the hardships we face

The constant causes of all suffering since beginningless time.
When I strive to conquer these innate afflictions—my natural enemies.
How could I possibly fall into despair over past failures or grow disheartened,
Even when wounded by hundreds of hardships in this spiritual battle?

If people proudly bear wounds inflicted by enemies without purpose
As if they were ornaments adorning their bodies,
Then why should hardships not be welcomed as purifying aids
By me, who strives diligently to achieve the supreme goal?

Fishermen, butchers of low caste, farmers, and others like them,
With minds fixed solely on their own meager livelihood,
Enduring cold, heat, and other torments,
Why then should I not bear suffering for the sake of establishing all beings in ultimate bliss?

I vowed to liberate all beings throughout the ten directions
To the farthest reaches of space from afflictions and karma
Yet at the time of making this solemn pledge I myself
Remain not freed from these afflictions

Not knowing the measure of my own capabilities
How could such speech not be that of a madman
Therefore, to conquer afflictions that bind me
I shall remain forever unwavering in this battle

Here I shall deliberately cling to the antidotes
And harbor enmity toward afflictions engaging them in battle
Such affliction-like mental states as these
Are exempt from abandonment when they serve to destroy afflictions.

Let my intestines spill out, let my head fall to the ground—
I would rather endure this bodily death than submit.
But in no way shall I ever bow down
To the enemies of afflictions, which lead to endless suffering.

Even if an enemy is banished from one's land,
They may dwell in other regions, establish themselves there,
And return once they've gathered strength anew—
But the foe of afflictions works not in this way.

Afflictions are abandoned by the eye of wisdom.
When removed from my mind, where would they go?
Where could they abide, then return to harm me?
My dull intellect alone fails to make effort.

Neither in objects, sense faculties, nor between them do afflictions dwell,
Nor elsewhere—yet where do these beginningless foes reside that torment the entire world?
These are mere illusions; dispel fear from your heart and directly confront them with wisdom's discerning effort.
Why needlessly harm yourself in hell realms when understanding their empty nature sets you free?

Having thus firmly resolved, I strive diligently 
To accomplish the trainings as they have been taught.
How can one afflicted with disease find freedom from illness
If they disregard the physician's instructions about their medicine?
This concludes the fourth chapter entitled 'Vigilance' (apramāda) from the Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life (Bodhicaryāvatāra).

One who wishes to protect the training
Should guard the mind with vigilance.
If this mind remains unguarded,
The training cannot be maintained.

When the elephant of the mind is left unrestrained,
It causes harm like the torments of Avīci hell;
But even a wild, intoxicated elephant
Does not inflict such suffering in this world.

When the elephant of mind
Is firmly bound with mindfulness' rope,
All fears shall vanish,
And every wholesome virtue shall come to hand.

Tigers, lions, elephants and bears.
Snakes and all who threaten as foes.
Hell's guardians who bring future terror.
Witches (ḍākinīs) and demons (rākṣasas).

Through binding this single mind,
All sources of harm become restrained.
Through taming this single mind,
All dangers become pacified.

Thus all fears and immeasurable sufferings
Arise from the deluded mind alone,
So taught the Buddha,
Who speaks only truth.

Who has purposefully created these weapons in the hells?
Who has made the blazing iron ground?
From where have those hosts of women arisen?
All these arise from one's own negative mind alone.

The Sage declared that all these various harms
Arise from the evil mind itself;
Therefore, in all three worlds,
There exists no fear more terrifying than the mind.

If liberating all beings from poverty
Is truly the perfection of generosity,
Yet many remain destitute even today
How could the former Buddhas have perfected such giving?

With all possessions including their fruits,
To every sentient being with generous mind,
The perfection of giving is declared;
Therefore, this perfection is indeed mind itself.

Where could fish and other beings be driven
So that they would not be killed
From attaining the mind of renunciation
The perfection of ethical discipline is explained.

Ill-mannered sentient beings are as vast as space,
It is impossible to subdue them all.
But when the angry mind is conquered,
It is as if all enemies have been vanquished.

Where would one find enough leather to cover the entire surface of the earth.
It would be impossible.
However, with just the leather of a shoe sole,
It is as if the whole earth has been covered.

Just as I cannot ward off external things,
I shall instead restrain my angry mind.
What need have I for controlling others?
With patience, my mind alone must be tamed.

What fruit comes from a single, intense mind of clarity?
Rebirth in the Brahma realm and similar states.
Body and speech actions yield many fruits.
With weak practice, this is not the case.

All recitations and austerities,
Though practiced over long spans of time,
When performed with a mind distracted elsewhere,
The Knower of Reality declares them purposeless.

The supreme essence of Dharma. If one does not know this secret of the mind.
Though seeking to attain happiness and overcome suffering.
They wander pointlessly without purpose.

Therefore, this mind of mine,
I must well grasp with mindful awareness and carefully guard.
Apart from the discipline of protecting the mind,
What purpose do numerous external vows and practices serve?

Just as one who dwells among the unrestrained,
Vigilantly protects their wound with great care,
Likewise, when living among those who provoke afflictions,
One must always protect this vulnerable wound of the mind.

If frightened by the slightest wound's pain,
I guard that wound with diligent concern.
When fearing mountains crushing in the hell of Saṃghāta,
why wouldn't I protect my mind's wound from its outward-leaking harm?

If one maintains such conduct,
Whether dwelling among evil people,
Or residing among women,
The steadfast practitioner of discipline will not falter.

Let my gains and honors freely perish
My body and livelihood likewise fade
Other virtuous deeds may also decline
But never shall my awakened mind deteriorate

To those who wish to guard their minds,
I join my palms in earnest supplication:
'With every effort, safeguard mindfulness,
And introspective awareness'—I join my hands thus.

Just as one afflicted by illness
Is powerless in performing all tasks,
So too a mind disturbed by confusion
Lacks capacity for all virtuous activities.

For one whose mind lacks vigilant awareness,
Knowledge gained through hearing, contemplation, and meditation,
Like water in a leaking vessel,
Neither remains in memory nor yields spiritual virtue.

Even many who are learned and faithful,
And who diligently apply effort to practice,
Due to the fault of lacking mindfulness and introspective awareness,
Become defiled with the stains of moral downfalls.

When the thief of non-vigilance (asamprajanya)
Follows in the wake of diminished mindfulness (smṛti),
Even though virtuous merits have been accumulated,
They are stolen away, leading one to unfortunate realms.

This band of kleśa-thieves lies in constant ambush,
Seeking vigilantly for every vulnerable opening;
Finding entrance, they rob our accumulated virtue,
And destroy even the life-force of higher rebirth.

Therefore, mindfulness—which guards the doorway of the mind
Should never, at any time, be removed from its post.
If it has departed, recall the sufferings of lower realms
And swiftly reestablish it to protect against the thieves of afflictions.

Through dwelling in the company of spiritual teachers
Following the preceptor's instructions
And for the fortunate ones who show respect out of fear
Mindfulness arises easily and naturally.

Buddhas and Bodhisattvas possess unhindered vision everywhere.
Their perfect sight misses nothing, like the sighted among the blind.
Before all of them I constantly abide.
Always visible within their all-knowing gaze.

Having contemplated thus that Buddhas and Bodhisattvas
Abide with inner shame, deep respect, and fear;
Thus Buddha-recollection will effortlessly arise
Within you again and again.

When mindfulness stands guard at the door of mind's dwelling,
For the purpose of protection against afflictive objects,
Then introspective awareness naturally arises to discern,
And even when it has departed, it will return again.

First I must examine my mind before any action
Discerning whether these thoughts are virtuous or flawed
When I recognize such afflicted mental states arise
I should remain like wood unmoved in body speech and mind

I shall never engage in purposeless wandering gazes
This I firmly commit to avoid at all times
With decidedly contemplative awareness
I'll keep my eyes lowered looking downward as in constant meditation

To rest one's eyes from visual strain occasionally.
One should mindfully look toward various directions.
If someone appears within one's field of view.
Greet them welcomingly after properly observing them.

On roads and paths, one should vigilantly scan
All four directions to detect potential dangers.
When resting, with composed demeanor
Turn fully to examine what lies behind.

Having examined for dangers ahead and behind.
One should mindfully decide whether to proceed or return.
Thus in all situations and bodily postures.
One should act only after understanding what benefits oneself and others.

I shall position my body thus
First establish this intent, then having restrained unnecessary physical motion
At intervals, with vigilant awareness examine
In what manner is this body now positioned

The intoxicated elephant of the mind
To the mighty pillar of Dharma contemplation
That it may never break free and escape
With constant vigilance examine with all effort.

One should diligently strive in samādhi practice,
Not abandoning its discipline even for a moment,
Thinking: 'Where is my mind currently engaged?'
Thus one must vigilantly scrutinize the mind.

In dangers and festivals and such situations,
If one cannot maintain all precepts, act as circumstances demand;
For during acts of generous giving,
Moral discipline may be set aside, it is taught.

When contemplating and beginning a dharma practice
Direct not your mind toward other pursuits
With one-pointed attention fixed on that task
First bring that very practice to full completion

Thus indeed, with focused intentional practice, free from distraction, all is well accomplished
Otherwise, neither foundational nor advanced practices reach completion
The secondary affliction of non-introspection, among the twenty afflictions
Will not increase when this sequential path is followed, guarding both mind and body from decline

When myriad forms of idle talk arise in various ways,
And wondrous spectacles of many kinds appear before all,
Though one may engage with compassion where duty requires,
One should dispel attachment whenever it emerges in the mind.

When pointlessly digging soil, cutting plants,
Or drawing lines in the soil without purpose,
Recalling the Tathāgata's training precepts with mindfulness,
One should, fearing karmic consequences, abandon such acts immediately.

When desiring to move about,
Or wishing to speak,
First examine your own mind,
Then, with steadfastness, act with reasoned discernment.

When you recognize your mind captivated by attachment
Or overcome by anger toward perceived objects,
Act not, speak not—apply the proper antidotes;
Remain like a piece of wood, realizing all phenomena lack inherent existence.

Wild and full of mocking laughter
Filled with pride and intoxicated with arrogance
Harboring intentions to expose others' faults
Seeking to reopen settled disputes with deceit

When faced with self-praise and vain boasting,
Or when disparaging others with criticism,
Amid abusive speech and heated conflicts,
Then one should remain still as a log of wood.

Should I desire gain, honor, and fame,
Or wish for an entourage to serve my call,
If my mind seeks personal service or care,
Then like wood I shall remain.

When my mind desires to neglect others' welfare,
Pursue self-interest,
Or engage in unnecessary speech,
In those moments I shall remain still as a piece of wood.

When intolerance arises, laziness, and fear,
Likewise reckless boldness and meaningless chatter,
When biased attachment to one's own side arises,
Then I remain like a log.

Thus perceiving the mind thoroughly afflicted by defilements,
Or engaged in fruitless, meaningless pursuits,
The bodhisattva-hero must, through proper antidotes,
Firmly grasp and establish it in virtue, unwavering.

With unwavering certainty in preparation, practice, and conclusion, deep faith in the Three Jewels
Steadfast through all hardships, respectful and reverent in conduct
Restrained by inner shame and mindful of how actions appear to the enlightened ones
Peaceful through restraint of the five senses, wholly dedicated to bringing joy to all beings

Mutually contradictory childish beings'
Desires do not discourage, and
When afflictions arise, these
Minds arise – with compassion.

In blameless activities I engage with purpose each day
Guided by concern for both myself and all sentient beings
Like a magical emanation with wisdom that sees no self
I shall always maintain this mind—conscientious yet free from ego

After long ages, having obtained this supreme moment of leisure,
I contemplate this rare treasure again and again.
Like Mount Meru, I hold my mind unmoved by afflictive emotions,
Training in moral discipline with this body that cannot sustain even itself.

Vultures consumed by their craving for flesh.
Drag here and there in all directions.
If your mind feels no displeasure toward them.
Why now do you give advice?

Why, mind, do you grasp this physical form as 'mine'
And protect it with food and clothing?
If you and this body are truly separate entities,
What possible benefit could this transient vessel have for you?

O deluded mind why do you not accept
This clean wooden figure as your self
Yet guard this foul mechanism of thirty-six impurities
That leaks filth from nine orifices what essence does it contain

First, with your discerning intellect,
Separate this skin's covering completely.
From the skeleton's framework, extract the flesh
With wisdom's sharp blade—find nothing inherently desirable.

Having separated the bones into their parts,
Look all the way to the marrow within,
Examine what essence exists in this,
Investigate this yourself thoroughly.

Having thus diligently searched with effort,
If you have found no essence therein,
Why now, through your manner of attachment,
Do you still protect this body?

O mind, consume not this impure body, |
Nor drink its blood, nor feed upon its entrails and fluids. |
Since these parts are wholly unfit for consumption, |
What real purpose can this body serve for you? |

For vultures and jackals, their future food,
Is it proper to guard this impure frame?
This precious human form, for all alike,
Is merely an instrument for extracting virtue.

Thus, even as you, the mind, zealously protect this body,
When the merciless Lord of Death ruthlessly snatches it away
And surrenders it to vultures and dogs as food,
What will you, powerless, be able to do at that time?

For a servant unfit for work,
Clothing and necessities are not provided.
Though you nourish this body, it will ultimately depart elsewhere,
Why then do you, the mind, exhaust yourself with such pointless expense?

Having given this body moderate payment in necessities,
Now let it fulfill its purpose: studying, contemplating Dharma, and benefiting others. One should not give everything to this hired servant
Without receiving the sublime benefits of spiritual practice in return.

View your body merely as a boat
For going to liberation and returning to benefit others
To accomplish the welfare of all sentient beings
Transform it into a wish-fulfilling Buddha-form

Thus, with mind as master of oneself complete,
Always maintain a face adorned with smiles.
Abandon frowning and all contracted features,
Speak with honest openness, a loving friend to all the world.

Like heron, cat, and thief who move
With silent stealth and gentle tread,
Thus bodhisattvas reach their aims
For self and others' good—so should they always act.

Of those skilled in offering virtuous counsel
Who provide beneficial guidance without being asked with reverence, place upon your crown the words
Always be a student to all

For all well-spoken Dharma teachings,
One should say 'Well spoken!' with joy.
When seeing those creating merit,
Generate delight with praise.

Praise others' virtues when they are not present
And when their qualities are lauded affirm with consent
When your own merits others recognize
Examine them with humble truthful eyes

All endeavors aim at happiness,
Yet such joy remains rare even when bought.
Thus, one should experience the bliss of joy
Through virtues accomplished by others.

For me there is no loss whatsoever in this life
In the future great happiness awaits
Through hatred and jealousy comes displeasure and suffering
In the future life great suffering awaits

When speaking, use words that are trustworthy and coherent,
Clear in meaning and pleasing to the mind,
Free from attachment and aversion,
And speak with a gentle, measured voice.

May I gaze upon all beings with straightforward, loving eyes,
Relying upon these very beings as fields of merit and generosity,
Through them alone—by cultivating bodhicitta and perfections—I shall attain Buddhahood,
Drinking them in deeply, like one quenching spiritual thirst.

Great merit arises from continuous intense dedication
Or when employing antidotes to opposing traits
When directed toward fields of quality, benefactors, or the suffering
These deeds yield magnificent results, as do their opposites

Having become skilled and filled with joyful enthusiasm,
I shall always personally undertake all virtuous activities.
Regarding all such deeds and toward anyone whatsoever,
I should not rely on others for their accomplishment.

The perfections (pāramitās), beginning with generosity,
Progress in order of increasing excellence.
Do not abandon the greater for the sake of the lesser—
Primarily consider the welfare of others.

Having thus understood, one should always
Be fully engaged in working for others' welfare;
For the compassionate one with far-seeing wisdom,
Even what is prohibited becomes permitted when done with farsighted compassion.

Share with those fallen into misfortune,
And those maintaining ascetic discipline.
Consume a moderate portion,
And give away all possessions except the three sacred robes.

One should not harm the body that serves the sublime Dharma
For trivial purposes or minor gains
By caring for it thus in this manner
One will swiftly fulfill the aspirations of all beings.

One should not relinquish one's life
When compassionate motivation is impure.
But when free from miserliness and regret, one should give this body
As a cause for accomplishing great purpose in this and future lives.

Do not teach the Dharma to those showing disrespect.
To one with wrapped head when not ill.
To those bearing umbrellas, staffs, or weapons.
To anyone with covered head.

Humble and profound and vast
Without men do not teach women
Toward both lesser and supreme teachings
With equal reverence always practice

A vessel for the vast Mahāyāna Dharma
Should not be directed toward Śrāvaka or lesser paths
One must not abandon ethical discipline and vows
One should not entice with sūtras and mantras while neglecting proper conduct

One should cover tooth-cleaning sticks and spittle when discarding them.
The disposal of urine and other bodily wastes
In water used for consumption or on common pathways
Is condemned by the wise and righteous.

One should not eat with a mouth overfilled with food.
Nor eat while making noise or with mouth gaping open.
One should not sit with legs stretched out.
Nor when washing hands should one rub both hands simultaneously.

One should not share vehicles, beds, seats, or dwelling places
alone with women who are not one's relatives.
All actions that cause worldly people to lose faith
should be identified, whether through direct observation or by inquiring from others, and such behaviors should be abandoned.

Never point with a single finger.
With reverence use your right hand.
All should use their hands this way.
The path should likewise be shown.

Do not wave your hands excessively when handling objects
When making slight movements, produce a signal sound
Use proper gestures like finger snaps with the right hand, all fingers extended
Otherwise, you will become unrestrained and face the fires of hell realms

Like the Protector in the nirvāṇa-bed's lion posture
Lie down facing your preferred direction properly covered
With full awareness resolved to rise swiftly for virtuous acts
From the very beginning apply this intention with certainty

The conduct of bodhisattvas
Is taught to be immeasurably vast;
Yet these mind-purifying practices
Must be steadfastly pursued until the mind is trained.

Three times by day and three times by night
Recite the Three Sections confession practice
Through reliance on the Victorious Ones and bodhicitta mind completing the four powers
The remnants of downfalls will thereby be pacified.

Whether by one's choice or others' power,
In whatever situation one engages,
The trainings Buddha taught that apply to each circumstance,
One should practice these with diligent effort.

There is nothing whatsoever that the children of the Conquerors should not learn in any field of knowledge.
For the wise one who abides in this way,
There is no action that does not become meritorious.
There is no merit that will not be attained.

Whether directly or through indirect means,
Engage in nothing but the welfare of sentient beings.
Solely for the benefit of these beings alone,
Dedicate all virtuous roots toward supreme enlightenment.

Never abandon the virtuous spiritual friend
Skilled in the meaning of the Great Vehicle
Upholding the supreme ethical discipline of bodhisattva conduct
Even for the sake of your own life.

From the liberation story of Śrīsaṃbhava,
One should learn the proper way of serving the guru.
This and other teachings proclaimed by the Buddha
Should be understood through studying the sūtras.

The trainings of bodhisattvas are seen in the sūtras;
Therefore, one should study the Mahāyāna sūtras.
As for the Ākāśagarbha Sūtra,
One should examine it at the very beginning.

The Śikṣāsamuccaya must certainly be studied time and again.
For therein is extensively displayed.
The constant conduct.
With its thirty-two ways.

Or alternatively, for now, one should study
The Sūtrasamuccaya, a concise compilation.
One should also, with diligent effort, examine
The two works composed by noble Nāgārjuna.

Whatever is not prohibited in the Buddha's teachings,
That very thing should be properly practiced by bodhisattvas.
To protect worldly minds from losing faith and to prevent wrong views,
Having studied the trainings, practice them with mindfulness.

The repeated examination of the states of body and mind
Again and again—this alone
Is what it means to guard introspective awareness, in brief,
This is the characteristic of introspective awareness.

With my body I shall practice these teachings.
What benefit comes from merely reciting words?
By only reading medical treatises,
How will the patient's illness be healed?

From the Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life (Bodhicaryāvatāra).
This is the fifth chapter entitled 'Guarding Introspective Awareness' (saṃprajanya-rakṣaṇa).

A thousand kalpas' accumulated merit
Generosity, offerings to Sugatas, and other virtuous deeds
One moment of intense anger can overwhelm it all
Delaying, though not destroying, their fruition

There is no sin like hatred.
No austerity equals patience.
Therefore, with concentrated effort, cultivate patience diligently.
Through various methods.

When the thorn of hatred lodges within the heart
The mind cannot attain peace or meditative concentration
Neither mental joy nor bodily pleasure is experienced
Sleep eludes, while equanimity and mental stability are lost.

Even those whom the master honors with wealth and rewards
And who depend upon his generous kindness,
When anger takes possession of this hateful, unfortunate lord,
They grow disillusioned and seek to kill him.

Even friends recoil from an angry person.
Though they may be drawn through generous giving, they will not serve him.
In brief, there exists absolutely nothing by which
an angry person can abide in happiness.

Thus anger, the great enemy
Brings forth forms of suffering.
One who, with disciplined effort, overcomes
Attains happiness here and hereafter.

Arising from the performance of unwanted actions
and the obstruction of what is desired,
anger—having found nourishment in mental unhappiness—
grows powerful and destroys me.

Therefore I shall utterly destroy
The nourishment of mental displeasure
That sustains my enemy
For this foe has no other purpose
Than to harm me
By destroying my virtue
In this life and beyond

Whatever may befall me,
I shall not disturb my joyful mind.
Unhappiness fulfills no desires,
While virtue diminishes.

If a remedy exists for a situation,
What purpose is there in feeling displeasure?
If no remedy exists for a situation,
What benefit comes from being displeased?

For myself and those dear to me,
Suffering, contempt, harsh words,
And ill repute are unwanted;
For enemies, the opposite applies.

The causes of happiness arise but rarely,
While suffering's causes abound and many.
Without suffering, no renunciation emerges.
Therefore, mind, be steadfast.

The devotees of goddess Uma and the people of Karnataka
Endure the pain of burning, cutting, and other torments
They bear such meaningless suffering for empty aims

One should cultivate noble confidence in three domains.
Actions, afflictions, and one's capacity to overcome them.
Thinking, 'I alone must accomplish this.'
This constitutes the proper pride in action.

This world, enslaved by afflictions, is incapable
Of accomplishing even its own aims.
Since beings cannot practice virtue as I can,
Therefore I myself shall undertake this task.

When others perform lowly tasks,
How can I remain here idle? If I don't act thus out of pride,
Better that my pride be destroyed.

When encountering a dead snake,
Even a crow behaves like mighty Garuda;
If my mind becomes weak and feeble,
Even minor downfalls cause grievous harm.

When, with dejection, one abandons efforts,
Is there any escape from suffering?
By generating pride and diligent effort,
Even great ones find it difficult to overcome.

Therefore, with a steadfast mind,
I shall defeat all downfalls.
If I am defeated by these downfalls,
My aspiration to conquer the three realms will become a matter of ridicule.

I shall conquer all
By none shall I be overcome
I, child of the Victorious Lion
Shall maintain this pride.

Beings conquered by pride suffer,
Not those with noble pride.
The nobly proud resist enemies,
Others fall to pride's power.

Filled with the affliction of pride
Pride leads one to lower realms of existence
Even in human rebirth, one's celebrations are destroyed
Becoming a servant subsisting on others' food
A fool like a pig, unsightly as a frog, weakly emaciated

Everywhere one becomes despised.
Those ascetics practicing austerities, yet puffed up with pride.
If even such practitioners are counted among the arrogant ones.
What can be said of these pitiable beings.

They alone are truly proud, victorious, and heroic
Who bear the antidote-pride to vanquish the enemy of afflictive pride
Who, having thoroughly conquered even the stirring foe of 'I am' pride that seeks to rule the three realms
Bestow upon all sentient beings exactly as they wish the fruit of victory: complete enlightenment.

When dwelling amidst conditions that trigger afflictions
Apply antidotes with a thousandfold intensity  
Like a lion untroubled by packs of smaller beasts
Let your mind remain unmoved by hosts of passions

Even amid great dangers,
As one protects the eye,
So too when facing hardship,
One should never fall under the power of afflictions.

I would rather be burned and killed,
Or even have my head cut off;
But in no way whatsoever
Will I bow to afflictions as my enemies.
Likewise, in all circumstances,
I will practice only what accords with reason.

Like children delighting in the joy of play
So should bodhisattvas be drawn to their virtuous deeds
Devoted to these actions never satisfied
Yet finding inherent happiness in this spiritual joy

Though actions are performed for the sake of happiness,
Whether they will bring happiness remains uncertain,
For bodhisattvas whose virtuous deeds themselves become sources of immediate and lasting joy,
How can one find happiness without performing such actions?

Like honey on a razor's edge that severs the tongue,
If worldly desires never satisfy, just increasing thirst like salt water,
How could one ever be satiated by meritorious nectar of the bodhisattva path,
Which brings both sweet ripening happiness in higher realms and the peaceful bliss of nirvana?

Therefore, to perfect this third power,
Just as an elephant scorched by midday heat,
When meeting a lake, plunges in,
One should likewise engage in these deeds.

When strength is depleted through spiritual exertion,
Set it aside with joy, intending to resume when restored.
Though a practice may be well accomplished,
Relinquish it, yearning for ever more excellent pursuits.

Like skilled warriors in sword combat with a trained foe,
Defend against the blows of afflictions with vigilance,
While striking forcefully at these enemy passions,
Fight this dual battle with mindful determination.

Just as one terrified in battle quickly retrieves
A sword that has fallen,
So too, when your weapon of mindfulness slips away,
Swiftly reclaim it, remembering the terrors of hell.

Just as poison, having entered the blood,
Spreads throughout the entire body,
Likewise, when afflictions find an opening,
They completely pervade the mind.

Just as one springs up instantly in terror
When finding a serpent coiled upon one's lap,
So too when drowsiness and sloth arise,
One should swiftly dispel them.

For each and every fault that arises,
I shall thoroughly reproach myself and,
Reflecting long on past harmful outcomes
By all means, I must ensure this fault never returns.

How shall mindfulness become thoroughly habituated
In these various states of practice?
With this cause as motivation, one should seek
Either association with virtuous Mahāyāna teachers 
or engagement in appropriate spiritual activities.

To ensure one's virtuous deeds have power from the beginning,
One should recall the teachings on mindfulness,
And make oneself light and ready to rise;
Just as before, one remains prepared for all actions.

Just as cotton is controlled by the wind's
Coming and going movements,
Likewise, through joyful effort one masters,
Thus prosperity and accomplishment arise.
Thus concludes the seventh chapter, called 'The Perfection of Diligence,' from 'Entering the Bodhisattva's Conduct.'

Having thus generated diligence,
Place the mind in meditative concentration. One
Whose mind is completely distracted
Dwells within the jaws of afflictions.

Through seclusion of body and mind,
Distractions cannot possibly arise;
Therefore, abandon worldly engagements entirely,
And completely discard all conceptual thoughts.

Due to attachment to beings and craving for gains and such,
One does not renounce the worldly entanglements;
Therefore, having completely abandoned these inner and outer attachments,
The discerning sage should contemplate thus.

Understanding that insight, when endowed with calm abiding,
Thoroughly destroys the afflictions,
First seek calm abiding,
Which is accomplished through genuine delight in isolated places, free from attachment to worldly concerns.

What impermanent being could rightfully form attachment to that which is impermanent?
Through such attachment, across thousands of births,
One will find neither joy nor their beloved again.

Not seeing the desired object, one finds no joy.
The mind cannot rest in meditative concentration.
Even upon seeing it, one remains unsatisfied.
Just as before, tormented by craving's thirst.

If one becomes attached to sentient beings, 
it completely obscures one from seeing reality as it truly is. 
Such attachment destroys the mind of renunciation 
and ultimately leads to being tormented by grief.

By obsessing over these transient friends,
This precious human life wastes away in vain.
Through attachment to impermanent companions,
The eternal Dharma leading to supreme liberation is destroyed.

If one engages with ordinary beings (bāla) through body, speech, and mind,
One will certainly descend to the lower realms of existence.
When they lead one away from the noble lineage's path of few desires, contentment, and renunciation,
What benefit is there in relying on such unwise beings?

In an instant they become friends,
In an instant they become enemies.
With fickle minds, they grow angry at what should bring joy and virtue—
These childish, ordinary beings are impossible to please.

When I speak what benefits them in dharma they respond with anger
They actively create obstacles to turn me away from virtuous deeds that bring benefit
If I do not heed their discouraging words and distractions
Angered at being ignored these childish beings accumulate karma for unfortunate rebirths

From the superior, one feels jealousy; with equals, one competes in rivalry.
Towards the inferior, one displays pride; when praised, one becomes arrogant.
When criticized with unpleasant words, anger arises.
When will one ever obtain benefit from childish people?

When associating with the childish—unless one is a noble being—
Self-praise, disparagement of others, 
And talk that fosters attachment to cyclic existence—
From such company, non-virtue will certainly emerge.

Thus, associating with childish persons
Only leads to mutual destruction
They have not acted for my spiritual benefit
Nor shall I become beneficial to them

From childish people—friends and kin—flee far away
If you must meet them, please them briefly with kind speech
Avoid developing any deep familiarity
Remain neutral and detached, like meeting strangers anew.

Like a bee taking honey from flowers without harm
I shall extract merely the essence of Dharma
Maintaining distance as if meeting all for the first time
I shall dwell everywhere without becoming familiar.

I have gained many possessions and honors
And many people are drawn to me with affection
If I harbor such conceited pride
After death, fear of the hell realms will arise

Wherever the deluded mind, bound by self-clinging,
Becomes attached to objects of pleasure and worldly gain,
Those very attachments, combined and multiplied thousandfold,
Rise up like an awakening old bear as intense suffering.

Therefore the wise should not become attached.
From attachment arises fear.
Since these things will by their nature be abandoned.
Establish your mind firmly and thoroughly investigate.

Many have gained wealth and possessions,
And though fame and praise have come about,
With these accumulations of riches and renown,
There is no certainty where one will go.

If others exist who criticize me,
What reason is there to rejoice in praise?
If others exist who praise me,
What reason is there to be troubled by criticism?

Sentient beings with diverse karmic dispositions,
cannot be pleased even by the Victorious Buddhas,
how much less by an inferior ignorant one like myself,
therefore, abandon all concern with worldly thoughts.

Childish beings disparage those lacking possessions
And speak ill of those who have wealth
By nature difficult to associate with
How could joy arise from such beings

Since childish persons are incapable of joy
Unless it serves their self-interest
The Tathagatas have proclaimed
'No childish person can truly be anyone's friend.'

In the forest, wild animals, birds,
And trees never utter unpleasant words.
When will I dwell with these pleasant companions,
Among whom life is peaceful?

In caves or empty temples
Dwelling at the foot of a tree
When will I no longer look backward
Becoming completely free from attachment

When will I dwell in places that no one claims as their own,
In naturally spacious and open areas,
Moving about freely at will without attachment -
When will I dwell?

Having just a begging bowl and the like
Wearing clothes that no one would steal
Even without concealing this body
When will I become one who dwells without fear?

Having gone to the charnel ground,
When shall I equalize my own body
With the skeletal remains of others,
Recognizing both as equally subject to destruction?

This very body of mine
Will certainly become so putrid
That even jackals repelled by its stench
Would not dare approach it.

Even this single body of mine
Its bones, born together as inseparable parts
Will fragment and scatter in separate ways.
What need to mention other beloved ones
Who've converged through separate karmic conditions?

Alone one is born into this world
And in absolute solitude one dies
Since none can bear another's burden of suffering
What purpose do dear ones serve who create obstacles to virtue.

As travelers on journeys seize and leave each dwelling place,
Just as they hold onto their stopping places along the way,
Likewise, those who travel the path of existence,
Fully grasp and cling to each birthplace.

While the world laments with tearful eyes,
As long as the four pallbearers,
Have not yet lifted the body from its place,
Until then, retreat to the forest.

Without attachments or enmities,
Dwelling alone with just this body in a secluded hermitage,
Having already considered oneself dead to the world,
When one actually dies, there is no cause for others to lament.

In mountain solitude, no attendants near.
Cause sorrow or distress through grieving here.
None disturb one's Buddha recollection.
Or Dharma thoughts upon death's liberation.

Therefore, I shall dwell alone in delightful solitude
Effortless, conducive to peace, and bringing joy
Where all distractions are naturally pacified
Such solitude I shall always cultivate

Abandoning all worldly thoughts,
With single-pointed attention examining only my own mind,
I shall strive for the meditative equipoise of mind,
And for its discipline, cultivating both aspects of bodhicitta.

In this world and the beyond,
Desires indeed produce calamities.
Here, they cause killing, binding, and severing;
Beyond, they generate hell, hungry ghost, and animal realms.

For whose sake, in the past, male and female messengers.
Making numerous supplications with joined palms.
For whose sake, without concern for grave sins or ill reputation.
Without hesitation risking dangers and exhausting resources.

Though I plunge myself into gravest dangers,
And exhaust my wealth in wasteful spending,
Those very women's bodies I embrace with passion,
Are but flesh-wrapped bones yielding false, fleeting joy.

Female bodies are but skeletons nothing more
Neither independent nor constituting a self
Though you intensely desire and thoroughly cling to them
Why not proceed to nirvana

That face, when lifted with effort, yet downcast through shyness.
Whether previously seen or unseen before marriage.
Now veiled with cloth according to regional custom.
Will one day be unveiled by vultures in the charnel ground.

Behold that face which once inflamed your passion
Now plainly exposed where once it shyly turned away
See how the vultures have laid bare what you jealously guarded
Why do you now flee in terror from what you once claimed as yours?

That which you jealously guarded from even others' gazes.
That body you so completely protected.
Now when it is being consumed by scavengers.
